hints_html:
What is the definition of continuity? At what x-value need we be concerned about the continuity of f?

A function is continuous at \(\displaystyle c\) if \(\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)\). That is, the left-sided limit, the right-sided limit and the function value are all the same.

question: B 06
sols_html:
Polynomials are continuous, so the only point where we are concerned with the continuity of \(f\) is \(x=1\). It remains to find a value \(a\) such that \(\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = f(1) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x)\).

  • By the definition of \(\displaystyle f(x)\) we have \(f(1) = a-1\).

  • The right-sided limit is \(\lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} a-x = a-1\).

  • The left-sided limit is \(\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^-} x^2 = 1\).

Hence we need to find a value \(\displaystyle a\) such that \(\displaystyle a-1 = 1\). It follows that the value \(\displaystyle a\) that makes \(\displaystyle f(x)\) continuous on \((-\infty, \infty)\) is \(a = {\color{blue}2}\).
